thread.title: What the front pages say: How Europe is covering the Greek crisis talks
thread.title_full: What the front pages say: How Europe is covering the Greek crisis talks

title: What the front pages say: How Europe is covering the Greek crisis talks
text:
Print 
As European politicians consider the possibility of a "temporary Grexit", we take a look at how newspapers around the continent have covered this weekend's frantic negotiations over the future of Greece 
The Greek crisis has been moving at break-neck speed this weekend but a bail-out deal today now appears off the table. Germany is openly considering a temporary five-year exit of Greece from the eurozone and a summit of the 28 leaders of the European Union has been scrapped. 
With negotiations becoming increasingly fraught, we look at how some newspapers across Europe are covering the weekend's events. 
= Germany: Welt am Sonntag = 
The broadsheet, unsurprisingly, leads with the headline "Schauble proposes exit". The paper reports that Germany's finance minister is pursuing an even harder line against the Greeks and that an unofficial discussion paper has floated the idea that the troubled nation leaves the common currency for five-years. 
= Germany: Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung = 
The FAS, the Sunday version of the centre-right publication, focuses on Greece's looming financing requirements and says "Athens needs at least 74 billion". 
= Italy: La Repubblica = 
= = 
Italy's centre-left paper also splashes on the ramifications of Germany's proposal of a temporary exit. "Tsipras divides Europe", says the headline, and the paper reports that the EU believes Germany's suggetion of a five-year "Grexit" is impractical.
